Award.AwardTitle: REBUILD: Changing the Culture of Introductory STEM Instruction at the University of Michigan

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Institutional Implementation project is building on the work of ten senior faculty supported by a strong research and implementation staff dedicated to changing the culture of STEM instruction and increase the use of evidence-based teaching. The process is one of Researching Evidence-Based Undergraduate Instructional and Learning Developments (REBUILD), an approach inspired by the strong progress made under an earlier NSF ADVANCE grant to this University. The goal of REBUILD is to advance a culture of evidence-based teaching through the work of a team of ten leading faculty members from physics, chemistry, biology, math, and education. REBUILD forms the vanguard of these reform efforts, providing an embedded center of expertise in evidence-based education, supporting more than twenty course reform teams across all of our STEM disciplines, and spreading through dozens of research-to-reform seminars in our department colloquia. REBUILD is leveraging the efforts of the existing Learning Analytics Task Force and the Center for Research on Learning and Teaching. It has clear visible backing from the Provost, Deans, and Department Chairs. REBUILD course reform teams include faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates in multigenerational collaborations that emulate the traditional research groups at this University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REBUILD project's name - Researching Evidence-Based Undergraduate Instructional Learning Developments - reflects it's central goal. REBUILD was launched to help science educators at the University of Michigan explore and implement the best new approaches to teaching large introductory STEM courses.

REBUILD brought together the physicists, chemists, biologists, astronomers, and mathematicians in a four year conversation, giving us all a chance to learn from one another, complete important reforms of some of our main courses, and develop a new, collaborative and scholarly approach to the design, development, and delivery of these courses. This collaborative approach provides many advantages, including offering excellent professional development for STEM education postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates - involving young scientists in education creates the future science educators the nation so desperately needs.

REBUILD made important contributions to the national discussion about STEM education, helping focus the attention of the national community on the teaching of foundational courses. Large foundational courses present special challenges which require special solutions. Students in these courses are especially diverse, coming from a wide variety of backgrounds, bringing especially various interests and goals. Traditional large courses do very little to respond to the dimensions of difference, offering the same modes of instruction, at the same pace, to every student.

As a result, foundational courses often fail to provide students with equitable and inclusive environments. To privide one example, REBUILD helped the nation to recognise important patterns of gendered performance difference in large introductory science lecture courses, noting that these differences were absent in lab courses. All of our students can learn introductory science topics. In traditionally taught STEM intro courses, many students do not. This work, since replicated on a number of other large campuses, helped to place a renewed focus on equity and inclusion as appropriate measures of success for large introductory courses.

Evidence of REBUILD's broader impact can be seen in two initiatives which it helped to launch.

The Foundational Course Initiative (or FCI) builds directly on REBUILD. Supported by $5 million in funding from the University of Michigan, the FCI promotes REBUILD's collaborative approach to large course instruction. The FCI's approach brings together a team of disciplinary experts from a department - faculty, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates - with educational experts from Michigan's Center for Research on Learning and Teaching - instructional designers, analytics and assessment experts, technology designers, and student support professionals. This team works on a class for three years, ensuring that by the end of that time all elements of the course have been carefully designed and able to be sustainably delivered.

The Sloan Equity and Inclusion in STEM Introductory Courses, or SEISMIC, project also builds on the lessons learned from REBUILD. Launched in 2018 with more than $1 million in funding from the Sloan Foundation, SEISMIC will bring together multi-disciplinary STEM reform efforts on the campuses of 11 major public research universities in a three year collaboration. In a way, SEISMIC is a multi-institutional version of REBUILD.

United by a focus on equity and inclusion as measures of success, the SEISMIC team will engage in parallel data analysis, coordinated experimentation, and a continuous exchange of speakers in an effort to create sustained change in large introductory STEM courses at the disciplinary, rather than departmental level. This unique collaboration uses approaches developed for large scientific collaborations like the Sloan Digital Sky Survey to attack the challenge of STEM education reform.  

The need to improve large introductory STEM courses has been clear for decades. Progress toward these reforms has been slow. REBUILD helped both the University of Michigan and the national community begin to imagine a new, collaborative, multi-disciplinary, multi-institutional approach to reform. It's successor projects, the Foundational Course Initiative and the Sloan Equity and Inclusion in STEM Introductory Courses project, are putting these lessons to work.
